description: From Middle English trouthe, truthe, trewthe, treowthe, from Old English trēowþ, trīewþ (“truth, veracity, faith, fidelity, loyalty, honour, pledge, covenant”), from Proto-Germanic *triwwiþō (“promise, covenant, contract”), from Proto-Indo-European *drū- (“tree”), from Proto-Indo-European *deru- (“firm, solid”), equivalent to true +‎ -th. Cognate with Norwegian trygd (“trustworthiness, security, insurance”), Icelandic tryggð (“loyalty, fidelity”).

entries.meaning: True facts, genuine depiction or statements of reality.
examples: The truth is that our leaders knew a lot more than they were letting on.

entries.meaning: Conformity to fact or reality; correctness, accuracy.
examples: There was some truth in his statement that he had no other choice.

entries.meaning: The state or quality of being true to someone or something.
examples: Truth to one's own feelings is all-important in life.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A pledge of loyalty or faith.
Conformity to rule; exactness; close correspondence with an example, mood, model, etc.
examples: The process of grinding is, in fact, regarded as indispensable wherever truth is required, yet that of scraping is calculated to produce a higher degree of truth than has ever been attained by grinding.

entries.meaning: That which is real, in a deeper sense; spiritual or ‘genuine’ reality.
examples: Alcoholism and redemption led me finally to truth.

entries.meaning: (countable) Something acknowledged to be true; a true statement or axiom.
examples: Hunger and jealousy are just eternal truths of human existence.

entries.meaning: (physics, dated) Topness; the property of a truth quark.
(games) In the game truth or dare, the choice to truthfully answer a question put forth.
examples: When asked truth or dare, he picked truth.

verbs.description: truth (third-person singular simple present truths, present participle truthing, simple past and past participle truthed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To assert as true; to declare; to speak truthfully.
examples: Had they [the ancients] dreamt this, they would have truthed it heaven.

entries.meaning: To make exact; to correct for inaccuracy.

examples: You keep lying, when you oughta be truthin'
